1.1: Extent to which increase support for sustainable NTFP production/use within private sector in Pakistan through BBRT [Scale = 1. Not at All; 2. Partially; 3. Largely; 4. Fully] 1.2: Number of voluntary NTFP certification systems established 1.3: Number of alliances with national & international buyers representing preferential markets for certified biodiversity-friendly NTFP from project CBEs 1.4: Revised regulatory framework for NTFP collection, processing & trade. [Scale = 1. Not at All; 2. To a very partial extent; 3. To some extent; 4. To a significant extent; 5. To full extent]
2.1: Extent to which conservancy villages & valleys receiving support for CBE development & management [Scale = 1. Not adequate; 2. Partially; 3. Moderately; 4. Mostly/Fully] 2.2: Number of operational CBEs with approved business plans participating in voluntary NTFP certification schemes 2.3: Extent to which Community access to relevant technical, financial and market information services for CBE development have been effective [Scale = 1. Not at All; 2. To a very partial extent; 3. To some extent; 4. To a significant extent; 5. To full extent]
3.1: Number of specific biodiversity conservation measures successfully implemented by project CBEs at landscape level under their Conservation and SRU Agreements. 3.2: Number of collaborative forest management initiatives developed and implemented by State Forestry departments and local communities. 3.3: Extent to which the developed monitoring system for community-based adaptive management of CBEs effectively enhance community ownership and ensure transparency. [Scale = 1. Not at All; 2. To a very partial extent; 3. To some extent; 4. To a significant extent; 5. To full extent]
4.1: Extent to which the capacity development of key institutions has been effective in providing technical and business support services to CBEs. [Scale = 1. Very Partially; 2. Partially; 3. Fully] 4.2: Extent to which project knowledge and lesson learnt have

comment.narrative:
1.1: 1 [Not at All} 1.2: 0 1.3: 0 1.4: 1 [Not at All]
2.1: 1 [Not adequate] 2.2: 0 2.3: 1 [Not at All]
3.1: 0 3.2: 0 3.3: 2 [To a very partial extent]
4.1: 1 [Very Partially] 4.2: 1 [Not used]

Mobilization of government own monies as support for the project implementation. GB government has banned annual auction of medicinal and aromatic plants to any outside contractor from the entire province, letting CBEs practice scientific collection and marketing of NTFPs. CBEs have been facilitated to purchase samples of NTFPs from the conservancies. Draft rules for extraction of NTFPs were developed which are currently under consultation with government. The process of review of existing legislation has also been completed in KP, where the government has deiced to engage expertise from the open market for the development of rules and procedures for NTFPs. Around 1000 tool kits each with 15 tools were distributed in CBEs for sound collection and processing of NTFPs in the field. 10 CBEs established through unanimous decision of local communities in the conservancies of GB and KP. Research and development trials of important NTFP species established in two Universities, each in GB and KP; 6 Master degree student were facilitated through provision of short-term research opportunities the conservancies. 10 Sustainable Resource Agreements (SRU) developed which are ready to be signed as trade off with communities for arresting illegal cutting, poaching and showing compliance to government rules and regulation in lieu of getting support from the project.

1.1: 3 major herbal industries in Pakistan to include reference in their CSR policy to preferential buying of certified NTFP from project areas. (Scale =2) 1.2: Voluntary certification schemes for sustainable production established for at least 2 NTFP including: a) Chilghoza pine nuts; b) Morel mushrooms. (Scale =2) 1.3: 5 operational alliances with international and national buyers representing preferential markets for certified biodiversity-friendly NTFP from Northern Pakistan. (Scale =1) 1.4: 2 comprehensive draft regulatory framework for NTPF collection & trade that supports sustainable NTFP production developed. (Scale =2) 2.1: At least 20 villages and 10 valleys receive training on the business and technical skills needed for successful CBE establishment & participation in voluntary certification schemes. (Scale 3) 2.2: CBEs with approved business plans participating in one or more NTFP voluntary certification schemes. (Scale=2) 2.3: A mechanism for coordinated delivery of technical, financial and market advisory services to CBEs in place and being used effectively by CBEs for business planning and development. (Scale=3) 3.1: At least 2 specific and quantifiable priority conservation measures included in 10 CBEs Conservation & SRU Agreements and integrated into the relevant Landscape Conservation Plans (LCPs). (Scale=3) 3.2: At least one collaborative forest management developed and under implementation in one conservancy. (Scale=1) 3.3: Participatory Monitoring protocols for 10 CBEs developed for community-based adaptive management to enhance community ownership and ensure transparency. (Scale=3) 4.1: Capacity development of at least 4 major partner national organizations/government agencies to support certified NTFP production by CBEs in northern Pakistan, mechanisms for providing ongoing support to communities for CBE development and certified NTFP production as well as for CBE scale up and replication. (Scale=3) 4.2: a) Community to community learning fac

1.1 8 companies visited the entire CBEs and negotiated products for sourcing, 1 invited members of 3 CBEs to Lahore for exposure and negotiated rates for Chilghoza pine nuts in bulk. Hunza organics signed the MoU with CBE Gais and purchased almost 30 tons of Walnut and 1 Ton of Pine Nuts from Hudur CBE.; 3 Companies visited European Trade Fairs and displayed products from the CBEs for onward marketing. 1.2 This is a process oriented activity, certification process is underway. The technical experts from FairWild and CBI visited the field again in July and October 2016. The documentation process was discussed and reviewed; training was imparted to CBEs, collectors and Business companies in both the provinces and the monitors. The FairWild auditor also visited one of the prominent areas for Chilghoza and assessed the potential. Most of the documentation is complete by now and the final assessment of the international auditors is awaited for certification or otherwise. 1.3 4 alliances have been established during the reporting period. 2 alliances are the communal alliances where CBEs of each conservancy grouped themselves into communal alliances. 8 business companies were introduced to CBEs, and were facilitated to the European markets with support of CBI for creating demand of the natural ingredients from the conservancies. On return, few companies like Hunza organics have made specific agreements with CBEs for sustainable sourcing form the CBEs. Officials of Dutch Organization PAKKA visited CBE Diamir and have collected the specimen/samples for scientific testing and marketing. 1.4 The existing legislation in Pakistan hardly provides any space for participatory management and business of NTFPs. The project reviewed the exiting legal framework in GB and KP and draft rules for extraction of NTFPs were developed in Gilgit Baltistan, which are currently under consultation with law department. While in Khyber Paktunkhwa, process of review has been also completed, where

description.narrative: Sustainable production of biodiversity goods and services through community ecosystem-based enterprises
1. Increase in income for NTFP collectors and villages participating in sustainable NTFP production through CBEs

comment.narrative:
1. Currently NTFP is collected by: nomadic grazers and poorer resident households. Women and children are the main collectors. Contribution of pine nuts and morels to average household income varies from site to site.
Baseline values to be determined in Yr 1 for the following: a) household income from pine nuts and morels in target valleys
b) Community perceptions of value of NTFP and expectations from CBEs in in target valleys

1. a) NTFP collectors obtain 50% more income from sale of sustainably harvested pine nuts and morels to CBEs than from earlier sales to local traders and contractors
b) Community members of least 8/10 CBEs satisfied with CBE performance and willing and able to continue CBE operations

The project is making regular progress in the direction set aside in the target. It is too early to quote any percentage for part a) however, the community members are satisfied with the selection process, initial meetings and tasks performed by CBEs. The open collection of NTFPs in the valleys is banned by the CBEs for outsiders. The value addition trainings have been imparted to collectors and a range of the NTFPs are collected and the information collected from the market on each species has been shared with CBEs. This has encouraged the CBEs to initiate a case with the government not to contract out the collection of NTFPs from GB to any outside contract in lumpsum, which is the routine practice of the government.

description.narrative: 2. At least 20,000 ha of critical habitat of target high value NTFPs protected for sustainable production of certified NTFPs in project conservancies

comment.narrative: 2. 0 Ha of forest under certified NTFP production

2. At least 5,000 ha of critical habitat of Chilghoza forest and 15,000 ha of other high value target NTFPs in temperate forest in Astore, Kalam and Dir Kohistan protected and under certified production of NTFPs.

The areas for high value target NTFPs are identified in the conservancies, meetings and discussions were held with communities to ensure conservation of the critical habitat through communal decisions. A range of relevant organisations were contacted with the purpose to explore certification for selected species of medicinal an aromatic plants. Finally, FairWild due to its comprehensive certification standard for sustainable collection, equitable distribution and health perspectives, was elected. The Action plan has been developed together with FairWild. The future plans of the project include an agreement with FairWild, visits by the experts to participate in the Business and Biodiversity Round Table BBRT) and visits of the auditors to the field.

description.narrative: 3. Landscape conservation approaches introduced resulting in improved conservation management of selected threatened species and habitats

comment.narrative:
3. Some conservation measures implemented by local communities, but not for the following:
a) Leaves of Taxus wallichiana (CITES Appendix I) harvested ilegally for fodder and as NTFP
b) Morel mushroom collection practices adversely impacts pheasant populations, including globally threatened species (e.g. White crested Kalij), through breakage and collection of pheasant eggs

3. Improved conservation management of at least 1 significant threatened species or natural habitat type each CBE valley:
a) No illegal harvesting of Taxus wallichiana (Himalayan yew, Cites Appendix I) in at least 6/10 CBE areas
b) Collectors in 6/10 CBE areas collect morels later in season to minimize damage to wild pheasant eggs

Conservation measures agreed with 4 CBEs for imposing ban on illegal collection of all CITES Species including Taxus Walliciana
The morels are collected by CBEs according to the Terms and Conditions agreed with the project including late season, right size and in selected pastures

description.narrative: 4. Strengthened institutional capacity for landscape conservation and CBE establishment and certified production of NTFPs in Pakistan

comment.narrative: 4. a) Considerable capacity, especially among NGOs, (e.g. RSPN, Sarhad RSP, AKRSP) for social mobilization & establishment of different types of village organizations, including, to a lesser extent, enterprise development Some national capacity for organic certification of agricultural /horticultural products. Little capacity among NGOs or key government agencies / dpeartments (e.g. PFI, KP & GB Forestry Departments & MINFAL) for promoting biodiversity conservation through certified production of NTFP by local communities or for delivering extension services in an integrated rather than sectoral way b) No agency in Pakistan has experience or training to verify whether NTFP production complies with agreed certification standards

4. a) At least 70% of CBE requests for additional capacity development support and extension services to be established in Year 3 are met satisfactorily by Year 4
b) At least one national body trained (and potentially accredited) to verify NTFP produced under certification scheme

4 a) The project is in its 2nd year of implementation
b) Several national and provincial bodies including PARC, NARC, Pakistan Forest Institute, NTFP department of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa have been identified for participation in the training program for possibilities of selection/ agreement to act as accreditation bodies under certification schemes.

description.narrative: Market demand for biodiversity friendly non-timber forest products (NTFP) stimulated
1. Increased support for sustainable NTFP production use within private sector in Pakistan through (Business and Biodiversity Round Table) BBRT

comment.narrative: 1. No opportunity for private sector to preferentially buy sustainably produced wild NTFP as no certification systems in place
1. At least 3 major herbal industries in Pakistan include reference in their CSR policy to preferential buying of certified NTFP from project areas

The BBRT has membership from major industries and related institutions in the private sector. Two meetings of the forum was held where most of the industries including Herb ion, Hamdarad and Hunza Organics committed to purchase the certified products once available with CBEs as preferential buying of raw material as part of their CSR polices. The industries showed interest in certification schemes and the process as well. The market study was discussed in length and it was found that that the market study is an inbuilt component of the FairWild Certification package. Work has been started on it.

description.narrative: 2. Number of voluntary NTFP certification systems established

comment.narrative: 2. Voluntary certification schemes for sustainable production established for at least 2 NTFP including: a) Chilghoza pine nuts; b) Morel mushrooms;

Work is in progress to explore the suitable certification scheme/s and the standard for at least for two species (Morels and Pine nuts) primarily in the European market.The market study was discussed with the consultant hired for the certification schemes. He has submitted his first deliverable and will continue work according to the TORS in the days to come.

description.narrative: 3. Number of alliances with national & international buyers representing preferential markets for certified biodiversity-friendly NTFP from project CBEs

comment.narrative: 3. At least 10 operational alliances with international and national buyers representing preferential markets for certified biodiversity-friendly NTFP from northern Pakistan

The concept of establishing conservancies alliance was shared with CBEs. The work is under way to create a strong alliance of communities for extended market support to CBEs. Communal alliances will be created by bringing CBEs together so that a consolidate approach towards accessing the market is obtained. Formation of such two alliances are under way each in KP and GB. Furthermore, on the buyers side, individuals and well collective meetings were organised with several companies for exploring the possibilities of forming national and international alliances.

description.narrative: 4. Revised regulatory framework for NTFP collection & trade

comment.narrative: 4. No comprehensive regulatory framework for NTFP collection & trade. A few special rules for some products.
4. A comprehensive regulatory framework for NTPF collection & trade that supports sustainable NTFP production

Currently, there is no mechanism of sustainable harvest of MAPs species except a simple procedure of contracting an outside individual for unmonitored exploitation in the provinces. The existing legislation pertaining to Medicinal and aromatic plants species was reviewed in Gilgit Baltistan(GB) and fresh rules were developed through a broader process of building stakeholder consensus. The draft rules prepared are under broader review of the related institutions, traders and community organisations in GB. The rules will be finalised in the next few months.

description.narrative: Strengthened capacity of local communities to produce and market biodiversity-friendly products
1. Number of conservancy villages & valleys receiving support for CBE development & management

comment.narrative: 1. Conservancy villages have experience of forming new village institutions and understanding of biodiversity conservation & SRU principles & a few have experience of enterprise development, but none have experience of certified sustainable production of NTFP
1. At least 20 villages and 10 valleys receive training on the business and technical skills needed for successful CBE establishment & participation in voluntary certification schemes

Eight CBEs were established and three of them were registered. Necessary training on record keeping and CBEs management were imparted to help them shoulder the responsibility of running CBEs as business entities. The training needs and assessment were completed in the entire project conservancies and training of best practices, of collection, post harvest processing grading, packaging and labelling were imparted in all the conservancies. Furthermore, Training of Trainers (TOT) for the professional staff of Forest departments were completed as extension service providers to CBEs in future.

description.narrative: 2. Number of operational CBEs with approved business plans participating in voluntary NTFP certification schemes

comment.narrative: 2. All Valleys have Valley Conservation Plans and Valley Conservation Funds. Some have community-based trophy hunting enterprises. There is no community-based certified NTFP production
2. At least 10 CBEs with approved business plans participating in one or more NTFP voluntary certification schemes
CBEs are sensitised through dedicated session for participation in relevant certification scheme for raw material of MAP species

description.narrative: 3. Community access to relevant technical, financial and market information services for CBE development

comment.narrative: 3. No extension services currently available to communities for biodiversity business planning or sustainable, commercially viable NTFP production
3. A mechanism for coordinated delivery of technical, financial and market advisory services to CBEs in place and being used effectively by CBEs for business planning and development

Dedicated sessions of the CBEs were organised with the government financing mechanism as support to CBEs. The formation of 4 CBEs and one national alliance is progress and will be completed by the end of June 2016. Such Alliances, once in place will provide regular advice on market fluctuation, demand and will link CBEs with the available institutions for technical and financial support to CBEs in the long run. Grants were provided to 8 CBEs as incubator funds for operationalising CBEs. Such grants will also be provided to the National Alliance for better coordination with the market/institutions and extended support to CBEs.

description.narrative: Positive biodiversity linkages strengthened at landscape level through CBE Conservation and Sustainable Resource Use (SRU) agreements
1. Number of specific biodiversity conservation measures successfully implemented by project CBEs at landscape level under their Conservation and SRU Agreements

comment.narrative: 1. Some biodiversity conservation measures are being implemented under Village and Valley Conservation Plans, which will not be duplicated in this project

1. At least 2 specific and quantifiable priority conservation measures included in each of the 10 CBEs Conservation & SRU Agreements and integrated into the relevant Landscape Conservation Plans (LCPs)

Developing Conservation Agreements is a long process. Communities were sensitised for agreements. Lengthy sessions were organised with CBEs and the relevant government institutions to agree on terms of partnership. The project has reached agreement with CBEs on arresting illegal cutting of forests, extending full cooperation to provincial forestry and environment departments, decreasing poaching and putting a ban on illicit and unorganised extraction of MAP species in 6 conservancies. These conservation measures are drafted in the conservation agreements, which will be finalised and signed between the relevant government institutions and the authorised community bodies Conservancy Management Committees/CBEs.

description.narrative: 2. Number of collaborative forest management initiatives developed and implemented by State Forestry departments and local communities

comment.narrative: 2. Not applicable as there is no collaborative forest management in the country.
2. At least one collaborative forest management developed and under implementation in every conservancy.

Mechanism of collaborative forest management has been discussed and agreed with CBEs. Joint consultations of the project, Forest and Environment departments and CBES in the field is in progress at two demonstration sites each in Astore and Kalam Conservancies for developing Joint Forest management Plans with support from IUCN.

description.narrative: 3. Number of community-based assessments of CBE performance, including economic and conservation benefits generated

comment.narrative: 3. Not applicable as CBEs do not exist yet. However, there is precedent of such assessments developed through MACP and continued through PMAC in relation to reviews of Valley Conservation Plans by concerned villagers

3. Annual participatory community-based assessments of CBE performance used together with project monitoring and any other assessments to adapt individual CBE management, including implementation of business plan and Conservation & SRU Agreement

Regular monitoring of the CBEs performance is under way with support from UNDP, the Ministry of Climate Change and the project itself. Capacity building events on CBEs operationalisation and management including administration and financial mechanism were organised. The project also completed baseline for MAPs species in all conservancies with support from IUCN. IUCN has been asked to initiate work on developing, testing and refining biodiversity monitoring indicators for the project and establishing participatory monitoring systems to be used by communities for assessing resource status, impact of interventions and recording changes for course correction.

description.narrative: Strengthened institutional capacity for scale up and replication of CBEs
1. Number of key institutions and agencies with capacity to provide coordinated support to mountain communities wishing to establish CBEs and participate in certified sustainable NTFP production

comment.narrative:
1a) Targeted institutions and agencies have considerable capacity in their sectors/ focus areas but limited expertise in supporting biodiversity-friendly, commercially competitive enterprises
1b) No mechanisms exist for coordinated delivery of extension services
1c) There is no partnership yet and hence no budgetary support for CBE scale up & replication other than through the cofinanciers of this project (MoE/PMAC & UNDP)

1a) Targeted capacity development of at least 8 major partner national organizations/government agencies to support certified NTFP production by CBEs in northern Pakistan, including KP and GB Forest Departments, AKRSP, Sarhad RSP, IUCN, PFI, MINFAL
1b) Mechanism for providing coordinated support to communities agreed and implemented by key partners willing to provide on-going support to communities for CBE development and certified NTFP production
1c) Committed budgetary support from the partnership of organizations to provide capacity development to communities for CBE scale up and replication

Orientation and sensitisation events were organised for the provincial and national government institutions, rural support programs and relevant industries for extending support to CBEs. Research institutions were engaged through establishing research stations for future support to CBEs. Students are engaged in the specific surveys and scientific assessment of various parents of MAPs species in the field. The provincial government of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Gilgit Baltistan have generously agreed to provide their own moneys from July 2015 onward as co-finaincing from Annual Development Plans. This will help strengthen the ownership of the government agencies and will also augment the project resources for extended support to CBEs and communities at large.

description.narrative: 2. Number of dedicated follow up activities to systematically analyze, document and disseminate project knowledge and lessons learned regionally, nationally and globally

comment.narrative: 2. No project knowledge or lessons exist as the project has not started implementation

2a) At least one synthesis report summarizing main project achievements and lessons in English and Urdu
2b) Community to community learning facilitated by arranging for non-project villages to visit successful CBEs.
2c) Project knowledge and lessons shared across northern Pakistan through PMAC, the Valley and Conservancy Management Committees AKRSP, Sarhad RSP and AJKRSP
2d) At least one regional conference bringing together local communities, government, NGOs, private sector and other key stakeholders to share project achievements
2e) One national conference organized through the Business & Biodiversity Round Table to share project knowledge & lessons learned with key national stakeholders

IUCN has been engaged to support the project in these particular activities. Thus a project website has been created and maintained through IUCN. Data on the MAP species, progress and various achievements of the project will be gradually uploaded on the website. Communal exchange visits, national and regional conferences will be completed by June 2016

description.narrative: Strengthening capacity of courts, increased access to justice, improved police services, legal aid, improved rule of law policies, and representation mechanism for men, women and other vulnerable groups in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

description.narrative:
1.1: Extent to which ECP internal institutional management is enhanced [Scale = 1. Not adequately; 2. Very partially; 3. Partially; 4. Largely; 5. Fully] 1.2: Extent to which the ECP delivers improved electoral administration. [Scale = 1. Not adequately; 2. Very partially; 3. Partially; 4. Largely; 5. Fully] 1.3: Extent to which ECPs engages constructively with stakeholders [Scale = 1. Not adequately; 2. Very partially; 3. Partially; 4. Largely; 5. Fully]

1.1) ECP internal institutional management is partially enhanced (Scale: 1=not functional, 2=very partially functional, 3= partially functional, = fully functional) 1.2) ECP partially delivers improved electoral administration 1.3) ECP-HQ will largely engage with stakeholders. 2.1) stakeholders will be fully engaged in constructive and inclusive dialogue on electoral reforms ( Scale: 1= no work, 2=very partially, 3= partially/upto some exetent, 4 to a significant exent) 2.2) Electoral framework will reflect international norms and good practices upto some extent 3.1)Civic Literacy among citizens, especially youth, women and minorities is partially enhanced. (Scale: 1=not enhanced, 2=very partially enhanced, 3= partially enhanced, = fully enhanced)

1.1 Achievment on scale= 3. 12 trainings conducted for ECP, UNDP met on a bi-weekly basis and provided advice and mentoring to ECP officials 1.2 Achievement on scale=3, UNDP supported the delimitation of 2 provinces, 5 local government electoral processes, and implemented a GIS polling scheme, and deployment of video training to polling offcials 1.3 Achievement on scale= 3, UNDP supported the observer accrediation process, ECP has improved donor, and civil society outreach from 2014, ECP does not yet have an institutional engagement with poltiical parties. 2.1 Achievement on scale= 2, the SPCER continues to meet and engage with the media, but has not consulted much with public. UNDP contributed 5 poliy papers and supported the committee both directly through chairman and indirectly through ECP
2.2 Achievment on scale=3, The electoral framework is in the process of being reviewed and expected to be improved significantly following the completion of the SPCER - and passage of a new unified law. UNDP has contributed signficantly to this process as per 2.1 3.1 Achievement on scale=3, UNDP with partners conducted 3 major grass-roots outreach campagins aimed at decreasing the barries for women to vote. 87% of the program budget was spent on improving women's participation) The provinces supported were KPK, Punjab and Sindh

1.1: Partially (Scale Value = 3) 1.2: Partially (Scale Value = 3) 1.3: Largely (Scale Value = 4)
2.1: Partially (Scale Value = 3)
3.1: Partially (Scale Value = 3) 3.2: Partially (Scale Value = 3)

1.1 3 (Partially) Achieved During 2016, the Chief Technical Advisor, Mr. James Littleton conducted over fourteen official meetings with the senior management of Secretariat of Election Commission of Pakistan (ECP). These included six meetings with the Secretary ECP, two meetings with Additional Secretary ECP, another two meetings with Director General IT, and lastly four meetings with Additional Director General (ADG) – Gender and Training on a number of different topics such as GIS polling scheme, development of capacity building strategy for ECP officers, activation of gender and disability working group, ECP’s media strategy etc. Additionally, there were various informal and/or undocumented meetings of CTA with the senior management of the ECP to share best practices and international experience, in order to enhance ECP’s institutional capacity.
Moreover, the technical specialist as well as the Civic and Voter Education Officer conducted a series of meetings with Additional Secretary, ADG- Gender and Trainings, ADG Public Relations (PR) and other Directors to discuss and share experiences on key areas such as Development of trainings curriculums, training plans, media trainings, Interpersonal skills and capacity development training program for mid-career officers, leadership and management training for senior officers, activation of District Voter Education Committees, design and distribution of information education and communication material etc. Through sharing of international best practices, the new Members of the ECP as well as the senior management of ECP learnt about the complexities involved in the electoral cycle, and also about their enhanced role for upcoming General Elections 2018.
1.2: 4 (Largely) More than the target
During the Year 2016, the project organized BRIDGE (Building Resources in Democracy governance & Elections) Train-the-Facilitator workshop in Islamabad from 11-22 April 2016, in which 24 participants were trained (21 from ECP).

1.1: 3 [to some extent]- UNDP participated in consultative workshops on the National DM Framework and continuously assisted NDMA in implementing their national DM agenda, including development of various strategy documents. NDMA was assisted in implementation of regional cooperation of the Heart of Asia Countries. PDMA Balochistan was assisted in finalizing the drought risk assessment and drafting their DRM law, whereas PDMA KP was assisted in the development of needs assessment and early recovery strategy of the July 2015 floods and October 2015 Earthquake. 1.2: A Letter of Agreement (LOA) signed with National Institute of Disaster Management (NIDM) and 25 capacity building events were conducted across the country during 2015 in which 769 persons participated ( Male 595 and female 174). 1.3: 2 - PDMA Balochistan was assisted in finalizing the drought risk assessment and drafting their DRM law, whereas PDMA KP was assisted in the development of needs assessment and early recovery strategy of the July 2015 floods and October 2015 Earthquake. 1.4: 3 [to some extent] DRM officials from five selected districts were provided trainings on community based DRM planning and were engaged them practically in CBDRM process in the districts of Tharparker, Ziarat, Jafferabad, Low Dir and Chitral.
2.1: 30 COs have been either formed or reinforced to take the lead on implementation of CBDRM. 2.2: 4 [to a significant extent]- 30 community-level mitigation and adaptation plans were developed. 2.3: 4 [to a significant extent]- 30 mitigation and adaptation measures were identified and implemented in the leadership of each community organisation. Throughout this process, the notion of risk-informed development was applied. 2.4: 30- • 30 mitigation and adaptation measures were identified and implemented in the leadership of each community organisation. Throughout this process, the notion of risk-informed development was applied.
3.1: 30- Seismic Design in Pakistan was published a

1.1: Scale 4; Functional review of national and sub-national disaster management authorities was carried out in various forms. UNDP participated in consultative workshops on the National DM Framework and continuously assisted NDMA in implementing their national DM agenda, including monitoring the progress of NDMP in Pakistan. UNDP assisted NDMA in implementation of regional cooperation of the Heart of Asia Countries. PDMA KP was assisted in the development of needs assessment and early recovery strategy of the July 2015 floods and October 2015 Earthquake. A session on Private Partnership on DRR was conducted with PDMA KP; to initiate more investment on DRR in the province. DRM officials from 03 selected districts were provided trainings on community based DRM planning and were engaged them practically in CBDRM process in the districts of Tharparkar, Jaffarabad, and Chitral. 1.2 0 - No consultation held on Sendai framework. 2.1: 73; UC-level CBDRM implementation completed, which covers 73 communities in 3 selected districts (Chitral, Jaffarabad and Tharparkar). Community-level mitigation and adaptation plans were created Mitigation / adaptation measured identified and implemented in the 3 districts. 2.2: 09; To complete the cycle of CBDRM as specified in the proposed in the CBDRM learning report, 09 mitigation schemes were implemented in the three districts. The mitigation schemes consist of various measures which had been implemented after the consultation of community members and village disaster management committees. The mitigation schemes were flood protection walls, raised platform as well as check dam. 2.3: Though no target was planned at the beginning of the year. However , village level disaster management committees (DMCs) were also established in all 73 communities and were provided with basic training of first aid, search and rescue. Mainly male members are from youth group but with at least 30% female groups. 2.4: 0 ( no target planned ) 3.1: 1- P

description.narrative:
1.1: Extent to which Government and Civil Society Organizations have enhanced understanding of drivers of violence and intolerance among youth [Scale: 1= (Not adequately upto 25%); 2= (very partially 26-50%); 3= (Partially 50-75%); 4= (Largely 75% and above)]
1.2: Extent to which project’s capacity enhanced to identify and implement tailored and effective youth centric interventions [Scale: 1=(Not adequately upto 25%); 2= (Very partially 26% to 50%); 3= (Partially 50%-75%) 4= (Largely 75% and above)]
1.3: Extent to which virtual incident mapping tool is developed and effectively operational [Scale: 1= (Not adequately); 2= (Partially); 3= (Moderately); 4= (Mostly/fully)]
2.1: Extent to which people’s engagement and satisfaction with community services among the target population has improved [Scale: 1= (Not adequately upto 25%); 2= (Very Partially 26%-50%); 3= (Partially 50%-75%); 4= (Largely 75% and above)]
2.2: Extent to which young people’s attitude towards armed and political violence changed [Scale: 1= (Not at all 0%); 2= (To some extent upto 55%); 3= (To a significant extent between 55% and 85%); 4= (to a full extent between 85% to 100%)]

comment.narrative:
1.1: 1= Not adequately (up to 25%) 1.2: 1= Not adequately (up to 25%) 1.3: 1= Not adequately
2.1: 1= Not adequately (upto 25%) 2.2: 1= Not at all (0%)

1.1. Scale-3: Partially (50%-75%) 1.2. Scale-3: Partially (50%-75%) 1.3. Scale-3: Moderately
2.1. Scale-3: (Partially 50%-75%) 2.2. Scale-3: (To a significant extent between 55% and 85%)

1.1. Scale-3: Partially (50%-75%) Description: In 2015, Youth and Social Cohesion Project partially enhanced the understanding of government and civil society organizations on drivers of violence and intolerance among youth by playing a key role in providing evidence based information to government and civil society stakeholders for informed decision making through in-depth research studies conducted in collaboration with national and international institutes and open source incident mapping platform. These interventions are especially relevant in the current dearth of objectively verifiable information on the triggers of conflict and violence among youth. For instance, the research studies identify various drivers of youth involvement in conflict in KPK. With UNDP intervention, a strong working collaboration with the Federal Planning Commission of Pakistan for knowledge and experience sharing has also been established on violence and conflict mitigation mechanisms. In this regard, the Planning Commission advises its Peace Development Unit (PDU) through updated information sharing and developing working relationships with likeminded government and civil society counterparts.
1.2. Scale-3: Partially (50%-75%) Description: The project capacity partially enhanced through various interventions such as intensive social mobilization and youth volunteerism. The project has identified implementing partners to provide technical support and to reach out to a large segment of the population. This has paved the way for project expansion in 5 other union councils of southern KPK to implement youth centric interventions effectively.
1.3. Scale-3: Moderately Description: The virtual incident mapping tool has been moderately developed in 2015. The project has developed the partnerships with the Government, Civil Society Organizations and Academia. It took a considerable amount of efforts in 2015 to develop tools and techniques of incident mapping. Now all the systems are in pl

1.1: Partially (50%-75%); (Scale value = 3) 1.2: Partially (50%-75%); (Scale value = 3) 1.3: Moderately; (Scale value = 3)
2.1: (Partially 50%-75%); (Scale value = 3) 2.2: (To a significant extent between 55% and 85%); (Scale value = 3)

1.1. Scale-3 (Partially 50-75%) In 2016, project has partially contributed to enhancing the understanding of the Government and Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) on the drivers of violence and conflict amongst youth by facilitating knowledge and experience interchange amongst them through monthly CoP meetings [[E01]]. These network meetings have successfully focused on various issues, suggestions and challenges related to peace building for future programming and replication of best practices by the network members [[E02]].
1.2. Scale-3 (Partially 50-75%) The research studies undertaken under YSCP have informed project expansion in D.I. Khan and inclusion of interactive theatre and exposure visit interventions as one of the research findings showed that interactive and creative learning reduce youth’s susceptibility to radicalization and violence [[E03]]. The project has established partnerships with corporate sector donors (Telenor) and international research institutes (PRIO). These partnerships have contributed in operationalizing community centres [[E10]] and developing the research capacities of students at the University of Peshawar (UoP) [[E11]].
1.3. Moderately The Virtual Platform for Peace and Development (VPPD) is recently operational [[E04]] and adequately coordinated with government agencies [[E05]] for them to express interest in its development and improvement [(E06:E07]] for future policy guidance.
2.1.Scale-3 (Partially 50-75%) In line with the project theory of change which establishes that provision of constructive alternatives and improvement in standards of living can help steer youth away from violence and conflict; The project has partially strengthened youth resilience through the provision of constructive alternatives based on skill development training, mentorship, and engagement in sports and recreational activities in selected UCs of D.I. Khan. The findings of mid-term evaluation [(E09]] of the project showed that beneficiaries (7,5

title.narrative: Reforms and Innovation in Government for High Performanc

description.narrative: The project intends to improve governance at different levels, track and monitor the implementation of vision 2025 towards the targeted results and improved inter-provincial/inter-departmental coordination.

title.narrative: Reforms and Innovation in Government for High Performanc

description.narrative: This initiative provides support to the Ministry of Planning, Development and Reform for public sector reforms and innovation for improved performance and service delivery, citizen’s satisfaction and reducing multi-dimensional poverty
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Reforms and Innovation in Government for High Performance

description.narrative:
1.1: Extent to which performance tracking is effective in government institutions [Scale: 0= Not functional; 1= Very partially functional; 2= Partially functional; 3= Functional] 1.2: Extent to which technical and financial resources are available and effectively utilized to deliver on performance targets [Scale: 0= No capacity; 1= Very partial capacity; 2= Partial capacity; 3= Capacity largely in place] 1.3: Extent to which institutions are transparent, accountable and responsive (redressal, access to information) for service delivery [Scale: 0=poor, 1= satisfactory, 2= good, 3= excellent]
2.1: Extent to which government institutional structures are lean and agile for improved performance [Scale: 1. No Change; 2. To a small/limited extent; 3. To Some extent; 4. To a great extent; 5. Fully evident] 2.2: Extent to which performance management system is effectively utilised in in government institutions [Scale: 0= No system in place; 1= system in place but Very partially utilized; 2= system Partially utilised but not effectively; 3= system is fully utilised but not effectively; 4= system is fully and effectively utilized] 2.3: Extent to which governance institutions are perceived to be innovative (INN) and Citizen Centric (CC) [Scale: 1=not at all; 2=Partially for CC but not for INN; 3= Partially for INN but not for CC; 4=Partially for both; 5=Largely for CC but not INN; 6=Largely for INN but not CC]
3.1: Extent to which the Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) methodology is effectively institutionalized to measure poverty [Scale: 0= Not functional 1= Very partially functional 2= Partially functional 3= Functional] 3.2: Extent to which MPI is used for key development policy decisions and resource allocation [Scale: 1. No Change; 2. To a small/limited extent; 3. To Some extent; 4. To a great extent; 5. Fully evident] 3.3: Existence of robust framework for SDGs [Scale: 0= Not functional; 1= Very partially functional; 2= Partially functional; 3= Functional]
4.1:

comment.narrative:
1.1: 0 [Not functional] 1.2: 0 [No capacity] 1.3: 0 [Poor]
2.1: 1 [No Change] 2.2: 0 [No system in place] 2.3: 1 [not at all]
3.1: 0 [Not functional] 3.2: 1 [No change] 3.3: 0 [Not functional]
4.1: 0 4.2: 1 [Very partially functional]

1.1 Government institutions are effectively tracking and managing their performance on a regular basis (0-2) 1.2 Ministries are able to utilize their increased resources effectively to improve performance (1-2) 1.3 Improvement in citizen's perception of public service delivery in terms of transparency, accountability and responsiveness (0-1) 2.1 Efficient institutional structures with clear work distribution are in place (0-2) 2.2 Performance aligned talent management system effectively operational in government institutions (0-2) 2.3 Improvement in perception of government institutions as innovative and citizen centric (0-3) 3.1 MPI report launched (0 to 3) 3.2 Multidimensional Poverty index informs resources allocation and public policies related to poverty reduction (0-2) 3.3 Effective monitoring and reporting on progress against SDGs (0-3) 4.1 MoPDR positioned as model Ministry (0 to 3) 4.2 Wide scale innovation institutionalized in the government for improved performance (0-3) 4.3 Perception of MoPDR as a communicative, transparent and innovation organization (0-2) 4.4 Perception of MoPDR as a public sector think tank on development issues (0-2)

(1.1) Performance Contracts with the 11 ministries have been drafted and are currently being reviewed by the Minister MoPDR before sending to the Prime Minister for approval. An Options Paper for the establishment of a KPI Tracking Unit to monitor progress against the Performance Contracts has been developed and submitted to the Minister MOPDR. Terms of Reference for focal persons from 11 ministries have been finalised. A detailed project proposal on SIGOB has been presented to the Ministry but no decision has bene taken. (achievement scale=1 )
(1.2) A proposal to train 1000 senior government officials on broad-based workplace skills for improved performance has been finalized. (achievement scale=2 )
(1.3) A Citizens’ Perception Survey to assess public service delivery of key urban and rural services has been finalized. (achievement scale=1 ) (2.1) A civil service reforms package (in five areas) has been developed and shared through a summary, with stakeholder ministries for their inputs. Various background papers and analyses have been prepared to support or explain the proposed reforms. (achievement scale=2 ) (2.2) A concept note for a Performance Fund has been developed and the government has allocated Rs 1 billion to the Fund. (achievement scale= 1) (2.3) The websites of three organisations (MOPDR, FPSC, Establishment) are being redesigned in line with good practices in office process automation, open data, and citizens’ engagement. The initial review has been completed and consultations to finalise the design has started. (achievement scale= can not be determined at this stage ) (3.2 & 3.3) The project has shared several ideas with the DPU for initiatives around SDG 16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions, including on reforms in the governance of health, education, judiciary and police. (4.1) The project has supported the MOPDR in several platforms that have helped establish and strengthen MOPDRs role as convener, coordinator, and creator and sha

1.1: very partially functional (Scale value = 2) [Description: Government institutions are regularly and effectively tracking and managing their performance] 1.2: Partial capacity (Scale value = 2) [Description: Ministries are able to utilize their resources to improve performance] 1.3: Partially (Scale value = 2) [Description: Ministries use e-governance to improve performance and management] 1.4: Partially for both (Scale value = 4) [Description: Government institutions show innovation and citizen-centredness in public service delivery]
2.1: to a great extent (Scale value = 4) [Description: High quality research is produced and it informs the reforms process] 2.2: partially (Scale value = 2) [Description: Stakeholders understand and agree to a broad range of reforms and endorse the implementation strategy]
3.1: Partially (Scale value = 2) [Description: SDG measurement and assessment methodology and reporting is partially standardized]
4.1: to some extent (Scale value = 3) [Description: MOPDR is recognized as a model ministry capable of leading change] 4.2: to some extent (Scale value = 3) [Description: Greater understanding and support for reforms amongst the general public] 4.3: all types (Scale value = 3) [Description: All types of research, learning and sharing is done and used to influence policy and reforms]

1.1: Earlier this year, the Performance Contracts for 11 target Ministries were reviewed by MoPDR. Last quarter, a summary containing these 11 contracts and the KPI Tracking Unit was sent to the Prime Minister forapproval which is still awaited. 2(Very partially achieved) 1.2:The draft Inception Report was contractually approved in a meeting held on the 28th of July, 2016. The Working Group composed of representation from the MOPDR, Establishment Division and NSPP/NIM met twice on 19th July and 12th August to review progress. Draft TNA findings based on FGDs and IDIs were presented to the Working Group in its meeting of 12th August, 2016 and it was agreed that the training content and focus required significant re-alignment. In addition, the MoPDR was not able to secure sufficient numbers of nominations (250 required for the first batch). In view of the above, it was mutually agreed with SOLF in a meeting held on the 17th of August, 2016 that the training would be deferred till these issues were resolved. MoPDR is now in the process of securing further nominations. A meeting was held with representatives from Establishment Division, NSPP, specialized training institutes chaired by the Minister MoPDR on 5th September, 2016. The draft ToRs earlier submitted to the ministry were discussed and certain changes proposed. Contact has been developed with Bangkok Regional Hub for possibilities of training and exposure visits. A concept note has being prepared and will be put up for the approval of MOPDR. 3 (Partially achieved)
1.3:A consultant has been hired to provide overall IT assistance to the MoPDR. Thus far this assistance has focused on the performance management dashboard (1.1.1d); MoPDR's web portal as well as e-courts reforms for ICT district courts (2.3.1a). The RFP for the development of web portal was advertised on June 9, 2016. Ten firms applied. Subsequent to technical and financial evaluation of bids, a vendor has been shortlisted. The procurement process

description.narrative: Sustainable Forest Management

The project supports the Government in contributing to economic, social and political stability in FATA through rebuilding livelihoods, establishing and strengthening institutions, advance reform and ensure efficient and effective service delivery.
